subject: Re: [junit] Test-friendly, but not caller-friendly?
msgSnippet: ... Exactly, which is exactly why you should be humble when you ship your code and open it up.  Assume that people will use it in ways you didn t think of, and
messageBody:
On 8/29/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> > I would. When you're an API writer, it behooves you to make your
> library
> > general enough that it can be used for cases you didn't envision, or
> you'll
> > make the life of your users harder
>
> I'm sorry, but I flat out disagree. You should put in what is currently
> needed, no more. Do not try to support use cases you do not envision and
> do not understand. The bottom line is that if you leave something out,
> you can always add it later. However, once you've shipped API it becomes
> impossible to take it away


Exactly, which is exactly why you should be humble when you ship your code
and open it up. Assume that people will use it in ways you didn't think of,
and make it possible for them to do so in ways that you control (always an
interesting exercise, by the way, it forces you to think out of the box and
to break your habits).

Michael showed a pretty compelling case where the vendor forgot to make
their methods virtual, and I've seen this mistake and more general ones so
many times in dozens of API's and libraries I wish people locked down their
code a lot less.

Real life example: a programmer on my team once had to do "#define private
public" in order to use a certain functionality. There was simply no other
choice. That's exactly what I meant above by "keeping control": if you open
your code in ways that you choose, you, the library author, remain in
control and remove the need for this kind of ugly hack.


Adding functionality without a clear use case is a recipe for bloated
> APIs that don't work particularly well.


I don't see why, if they are carefully designed. Document the extension
points, and draw a clear line between what is exposed and will be supported
and what might change from one release to the next.

Without this mindset, frameworks such as Spring or Eclipse would never
exist.


> Same thing if your API will be reading data: make it possible for this
> data
> > to come from virtually any possible source: file, stream, iterator,
> > network, database, etc...
>
> In Java this is usually no big deal because it's all just streams (or
> readers). There's enough abstraction built into the core libraries to
> handle this. How this tends to work in C++, I don't know.


Yes, the Java libraries support the "open open principle" very well in
java.io, at the cost of some added verbosity (a small price to pay in my
opinion).
